It is an active volcano, most recently erupting in 1999 and 2000, resulting in landslides and lava flows (Ateba et al. 2009).
population: Only very few specimens have been collected suggesting that it is an uncommon species.
range: This species, along with the closely related Otomys occidentalis, are the most westerly occurring species of the genus (Taylor et al. 2014). Burton’s Vlei Rat is known only from the region of the type locality of Mount Cameroon, in Cameroon. It occurs from 2,000 to 4,000 m asl (Dieterlen and Van der Straeten 1992, Musser and Carleton 2005).
conservationActions: Mount Cameroon National Park covers much of the mountain.

rationale: This species has been listed as Vulnerable D2 because the species is found in a single location, Camiguin Island, where there is forest loss at lower elevations, which might extend to higher elevations in the future.
habitat: The species occurs in montane and mossy forest and areas which are subject to natural disturbance caused by volcanoes and landslides, there is little or no old growth forest here because of this disturbance. It is possible that the species remains in lower elevation habitats, including disturbed areas (L. Heaney pers. comm). It has been reported at an elevation range from 900 m to 1,475 m (Rickart et al. 2002).
threats: If the species remains in lower elevation areas, it may be affected by habitat loss due to slash and burn agriculture, logging, urbanization and increased tourism; it is less threatened at higher elevation areas where logging and deforestation occur to a lesser degree and areas of intact forest remain (L. Heaney pers. comm. 2006).
population: The population is likely to comprise of less than 10,000 individuals (L. Heaney pers. comm. 2006). This is a relatively common in suitable habitat (L. Heaney pers. comm.), but it occurs at lower densities than Apomys camiguinensis which is tolerant of a wider range of habitats.
range: This species is endemic to the Philippines and is restricted to Camiguin island (Heaney et al. 1998). It has been recorded from 900 m to 1,475 m asl. (Rickart et al. 2002).
conservationActions: The species is found in Timboong Hibok-hibok Natural Monument.

rationale: This species is listed as Near Threatened because it has a very restricted range (extent of occurrence of less than 100 km<sup>2</sup>) and some plausible threats (volcanic ash, habitat destruction due to agriculture). Currently the threats are unlikely to be severe enough to cause the species to rapidly become Critically Endangered or Extinct. A future volcanic eruption or increase in agricultural activity would increase the threats and qualify the species for Vulnerable (D2).
habitat: This species occurs in montane humid forest and possibly forest borders.
threats: Volcanic ash may be a threat to this species. Much of forest in the region where the species was originally found has been destroyed for agriculture (fruits and vegetables). Currently there is not much ongoing destruction of the remaining habitat, which is on slopes too steep for agriculture.
population: This species is known from the type description of six specimens from the first half of the 20th century, a photograph from 2008, and a few specimens collected in 2012 (Aquirre-Peñafiel 2012). The population trend is unknown.
range: The species is endemic to Ecuador, and Kizirian (1996) believed that most likely the type locality is Baños in the Río Pastaza Valley near Volcan Tungurahua, Provincia Tungurahu. Doan (2003) reported its elevational range as 1,800 to 3,150 meters. Sánchez-Pacheco et al. (2012) reviewed the taxonomy of this genus in Ecuador and confirmed the identity of the type locality. These authors examined Riama material from Colombia for comparison and found no evidence that this species occurs there, or that it has been found anywhere away from the type locality. In addition, there are four records from El Triunfo, Tungaragua, from 2012 (Aguirre-Peñafiel 2012). The elevational range is from 1800-3150 m asl.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is not known from any protected area, and no large protected areas are located near where the species is recorded, although there are some small private reserves. More survey effort using appropriate techniques for terrestrial lizards are needed to determine the population size, trend, and adaptability to disturbed habitats.

rationale:
The Volcano Rabbit is endemic to a small region along the Transverse Neovolcanic Belt in central Mexico where it occupies a restricted and specialized habitat on five mountain massifs (Velazquez and Gopar-Merino 2018). This range is becoming increasingly fragmented and the area of available suitable habitat is decreasing (Velazquez 1994, Rizo-Aguilar et al. 2016, Velazquez and Gopar-Merino 2018, Uriostegui-Velarde et al. 2018). This rabbit is being threatened by competition with grazing livestock, increasing frequency of fire, intrusion by humans (settlements, roads, etc.), and climate change. Models extrapolating its persistence in a metapopulation context under climate change indicate that it is likely to be severely impacted (Anderson et al. 2009). Its current EOO is 2,469 km², and an overestimate of the AOO is <444 km² (based on the sum of 19 relatively large habitat polygons, in which the species is further fragmented). The high level of current fragmentation and the multitude of ongoing threats are likely to lead to further decreases in area occupied. Thus, the Volcano Rabbit qualifies for Endangered status (EN B1ab(i,ii,iii,v) + B2ab(i,ii,iii,v)).

Reports that the Volcano Rabbit has gone extinct in the vicinity of the Nevado de Toluca (Mexico Daily News 2018) are false. Native populations of the Volcano Rabbit have never been in the Nevado de Toluca. A colony was introduced in the 1970s and sometime later a single individual was captured and taken into captivity, since then there have been no verified records of the species in this area. The Nevado de Toluca is not included in the current distribution map for the species.
habitat:
The Volcano Rabbit is a habitat specialist (Velazquez et al. 1993, Uriostegui-Velarde et al. 2018, Velázquez and Gopar-Merino 2018). It is found at its highest density in a subalpine habitat containing bunchgrass (“zacaton”) and pine communities (Velazquez et al. 1993, Hunter and Cresswell 2015, Rizo-Aguilar et al. 2015). The largest remaining area of preferred habitat resides in the Iztaccihuatl-Popocatepetl National Park, between 3,400 and 4,200 m (Hunter and Cresswell 2015). A study conducted on the Iztaccihuatl volcano found that preference was shown for areas that had low occurrence of “closed forest, long grass, cattle grazing, hunting, bare ground and incline” (Hunter and Cresswell 2015). Contrary to previous findings, the study suggested that an increase of recent fire activity resulted in increased abundance of the rabbit, resulting from improved habitat quality from reduced competition to bunchgrass (Hunter and Cresswell 2015). However, regular use of fire to benefit cattle grazing is not recommended given that cattle grazing proved to be more detrimental to the Volcano Rabbit than the benefit of improved habitat quality (Hunter and Cresswell 2015). Further, prevalence of fire led to a decrease in population persistence (VORTEX modeling, Portales et al. 1997). A second study in the Ajusco-Chichinautzin Mountain Range found that, in addition to the previously mentioned factors, proximity to highways and population centers had a negative impact on abundance, although this study did not find a correlation with regard to slope (the effect of fire was not examined) (Uriostegui-Velarde et al. 2018).

Until today, habitat fragmentation has not resulted in the loss of genetic variability, nor has it affected the genetic structure of Volcano Rabbit populations. The values of genetic diversity are similar in populations that live in a connected landscape and those that live in an unconnected one. In addition, gene flow has been detected even in isolated populations (Montes-Carreto et al., in press).

The diet of the Volcano Rabbit is diverse. It is known to consume more than 70 plant species, although the rabbits consume with greater frequency zacatonales of the genera Muhlenbergia, Festuca, and Jarava (Cervantes and Martínez 1992, Martínez-García et al. 2012, Mancines-Arellano 2017). In areas where bunchgrass is less abundant, they give birth in cracks and abandoned burrows (Velazquez et al. 1993). It is unlikely that the Volcano Rabbit constructs burrows of its own (Fa and Bell 1990). Gestation time for this species is 38-40 days (Cervantes et al. 1990). It may be reproductively active year-round with a peak breeding season occurring "during the warm, rainy summer" (Cervantes et al. 1990). Litter size is one to three (Velazquez and Gopar-Merino 2018). Adults in a captive breeding program weighed 400-600 g, with birth weights for females 25-27 g and males 32 g (Matsuzaki et al. 1982). Total length of newborns ranges from 8.3-10.6 cm (Cervantes et al. 1990). Mean total length of adults range between 26.8-32.0 (Cervantes et al. 1990). Most activity occurs in the morning and late afternoon (Velazquez and Gopar-Merino 2018).

A study conducted in the Itxa-Popo National Park found that the Volcano Rabbit makes up 12.5% and 5.5% of the prey base for the Bobcat (Lynx rufus) and Coyote (Canis latrans), respectively (Garcia et al. 2014). Additional predators include the Long-tailed Weasel (Mustela frenata), Red-tailed Hawks (Buteo jamaicensis), and rattlesnakes (Crotalus spp.) (Cervantes-Reza 1981, Velazquez and Gopar-Merino 2018).
threats:
The Volcano Rabbit is threatened by habitat destruction, caused by livestock grazing, agriculture and property development encroachment, logging, harvest of the “zacaton” grasses, and fires (98% of which are started by humans attempting to encourage new pasture growth) (Fa and Bell 1990). Its range is within 45 minutes of one of the world’s largest cities (Mexico City) and urban expansion has resulted in habitat loss (Fa and Bell 1990), which is ongoing. Today, suitable habitat for the Volcano Rabbit in the Ajusco-Chichinautzin Mountains covers 7,544 ha, equivalent to only 13.68% of the landscape, including 957 patches: 293 have a minimum area of 0.25 ha and only two are larger than 1,000 ha (Uriostegui-Velarde et al 2018). Though hunting is illegal, it continues because of lack of local knowledge of its protected status, and lack of enforcement (Cervantes et al. 1990, Fa and Bell 1990, Velázquez and Gopar-Merino 2018).

Reduction of habitat quality associated to the presence of pasture lands, crops, and roads may have a stressful effect on the rabbits, as mean cortisol metabolites levels measured in its faeces were more than two times higher in highly degraded habitat compared to the low degraded habitat (Rizo-Aguilar et al. 2014).

Climate change is likely to have severe consequences for this species. Anderson et al. (2009) predicted that the lower elevation range limit of the Volcano Rabbit may shift upslope by approximately 700 m during the next 100 years, which will reduce the area occupied by the species, as the mountain peaks currently lack suitable habitat.
population:
An early estimate of the population of the Volcano Rabbit was 7,085 rabbits; 1,811 individuals in Pelado, 1,816 in Tlaloc, 3,458 in Izta-Popo and approximately 3,056 for the surrounding areas (Portales et al. 1997). Due to a variety of continuous and ongoing threats, its population is likely to be lower at the present time.

Population densities estimated by line transects are variable between regions. Studies conducted on the Pelado Volcano indicated that densities ranged from 0.11 to 1.2 rabbits/ha according to habitat characteristics (Velázquez 1994); in the Biological Corredor Chichinautzin the density was estimated to be 4.2 individuals/ha (Rizo-Aguilar et al. 2016). Other studies have shown the relative abundance based on fecal pellet counts is also highly variable throughout its distribution, ranging from 0.1 to 3.1 latrines/m² in habitat on the Volcano Pelado (Velázquez 1994, Velázquez and Heil 1996), and 0.02 to 0.12 latrines/m² in Sierra Chichinautzin (Rizo-Aguilar et al. 2015).

The only study that has monitored trends in population was conducted in a core population in the Sierra Chichinautzin based on density estimates using pellet counts (Guerrero et al. in press). This study indicated that Volcano Rabbit density declined from 4.2 individuals/ha in 2011 to <1 individual/ha in 2017.

Initial studies indicated that the Volcano Rabbit occupied fragmented habitat, and that there were 16 discrete occupied habitat fragments (Portales et al. 1997); the current number of isolated habitat polygons is 19. More recent evaluation of the degree of fragmentation within occupied habitat polygons was able to discern significantly more fine-scale Volcano Rabbit habitat fragmentation (Uriostegui-Velarde et al. 2018). At the landscape level 957 patches of available habitat covering 75.44 km² were identified along the Ajusco-Chichinautzin Mountain Range (thus encompassing Tlaloc Volcano, Pelado Volcano, and Coajomulco forests), most (N = 293) of which had a minimum area of 2,500 m². Only two patches were larger than 1,000 ha. 144 plots were sampled intensively, and of these 50 contained no evidence of Volcano Rabbit presence (no latrines were located); on only five plots were there more than 100 latrines, indicating the presence of a highly viable population (Uriostegui-Velarde et al. 2018).
range:
The Volcano Rabbit is endemic to Mexico, restricted to the Transverse Neovolcanic Belt, mainly in discontinuous patches on four volcanoes (Popocatepetl, Iztaccihuatl, El Pelado, Tlaloc) and the Sierra Chichinautzin (Rizo-Aguilar et al.2016, Velázquez and Gopar-Merino 2018). An initial estimate of area of occupancy (AOO) was approximately 386 km² based on occupancy on the four volcanoes (Velazquez 1994), although this area has subsequently been reduced to 335 km². Recent observations, based on latrine records and sightings in the Biological Corridor Chichinautzin, have added 109 km² to this distribution (Rizo-Aguilar et al. 2016). A recent survey in the Parque Ecoturístico Piedra Canteada, along the Tlaxcala/Puebla border, north of Iztaccihuatl, yielded a recent siting of Volcano Rabbits, but the extent is unknown (Ramírez-Albores et al.2014). As a result of the over 15 years continuous volcanic activity of the Popocatepetl Volcano, the distribution range has shifted and expanded, locally. Currently, the discontinuous EOO is 2,469 km². The whole range, however, is becoming increasingly fragmented as a result of human-induced and natural causes (Uriostegui-Velarde et al. 2018, Velazquez and Gopar-Merino 2018).

The Volcano Rabbit occurs between 2,900 m and 4,250 m in elevation (Rizo-Aguilar et al. 2015, 2016), but its highest density is found between 3,150 m and 3,400 m (Velazquez 1994).
useTrade: In some areas, this species is hunted for food.
conservationActions:
The Volcano Rabbit is listed under Appendix I of CITES (1973), although the species has never been involved in international trade and this listing is apparently an historical artifact. Hunting is illegal according to Mexican law, but poorly enforced (Fa and Bell 1990, Velázquez and Gopar-Merino 2018). It is listed as endangered in the Mexican Official Norm NOM-059-SEMARNAT-2010 (SEMARNAT 2010). It occurs within the protected areas Izta-Popo and Zoquiapan National Parks, but hunting, grazing, and grass burning persist within the park boundaries (Cervantes et al. 1990, Fa and Bell 1990, Velázquez et al. 1993, Velázquez and Gopar-Merino 2018).

Captive breeding programs have been established with some success, but infant mortality in captivity is very high (Fa and Bell 1990).

It is recommended that conservation measures focus on habitat management, particularly the control of burning and overgrazing of the bunchgrass “zacaton” habitat, and enforcement of the existing laws prohibiting hunting and trade of the Volcano Rabbit (Fa and Bell 1990, Hunter and Cresswell 2015, Velázquez and Gopar-Merino 2018). Management of the protected areas should be improved and education plans at local, national, and international levels should be implemented (Fa and Bell 1990, Portales et al. 1997, Hunter and Cresswell 2015, Velázquez and Gopar-Merino 2018). Captive colonies, especially those in the zoos of Mexico City should be used to educate the public about the protected status of the Volcano Rabbit (Fa and Bell 1990, Velázquez and Gopar-Merino 2018).

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in XX threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 1,781 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat in Neuquén province, Argentina.
habitat: This is a semi-aquatic species associated with both small alpine/montane lakes and streams in volcanic tablelands with semidesert vegetation or open woods of Araucaria araucana and Nothofagus antarcticus (Cei 1976). This species also may be found in habitats slightly disturbed by horses and livestock (B. Blotto and C. Úbeda pers. obs.). Breeding takes place in streams and ponds (Úbeda et al. 2012) Its larvae was described by Barrasso et al. (2016). Larval development is prolonged (C. Úbeda pers. obs. January 2000, 2001), with one or more years overwintering in the water. Tadpoles of different cohorts (from diferent years) coexist in the same habitat.
threats: The ongoing introduction of exotic predatory fish, mainly trout, into the stream habitats of this species is considered to be a major threat. Another threat is the presence of livestock (horses, sheep and goats) which trample in the water bodies and neighboring areas <span class="datalabel1">(B. Blotto and C. Úbeda pers. obs.). Volcanic activity could affect this species' habitat (B. Blotto and C. Úbeda pers. comm. September 2017).
population: Is a relatively common species in suitable habitats and common in pristine aquatic habitats (B. Blotto and C. Úbeda pers. comm. September 2017). Although, there is a presumed retraction of historical subpopulations due to invasion of streams by salmonids (B. Blotto and C. Úbeda pers. obs. 2000 and 2001), which remains a threat to the global population. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from Lonco Luan Plateu, Primeros Pinos and nearby areas, and Moquehue stream (Aluminé Department) in Neuquén province, Argentina (Cei 1976 1987, Barrasso et al. 2016). It was also found in Batea Mahuida Pond and Caviahue, Neuquén Province (C. Úbeda pers. obs. Jannuary 2000 and 2001). Its elevational range is from 1,500–2,100 m asl, its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,781 km2, and all individuals are considered to occur in five or fewer threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The species is poorly protected; its range is partially included in Batea Mahuida Reserve and Copahue Reserve in Neuquén Province, and probably occurs in Lanín National Park.

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required at sites where this species is known to occur.

Research Needed
Population and demographic studies are required to better understand this species with and without the presence of exotic fishes, and to understand the limits of its geographical distribution. Further taxonomic work is also needed.

rationale: Riama balneator is a forest specialist with a restricted range. It is listed as Endangered because its estimated extent of occurrence is approximately 300 km², all individuals are found in one location around the type locality, and it is threatened by conversion of land to agriculture, mining activity, and potential future volcanic activity. Conservation measures are required to reduce the rate of habitat degradation occurring, and population monitoring of this species is recommended.
habitat: This species is found in moist montane forest habitat.
threats: This species is found within a region that is threatened by high rates of habitat degradation as a result of agricultural expansion and mining operations. The restricted range of this species may present a threat, as it is more vulnerable to stochastic events. The volcanic activity of Tungurahua volcano can be considered a major future threat.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species' type locality is within the Rio Puela Valley (Rio Pastaza Drainage) on the southern versant of Tungurahua volcano, Ecuador, at 2,750 m asl. Since the type locality was described this species has been found nearby, on the eastern slope of the Tungurahua volcano, San Antonio Mountains (Reyes-Puig et al. 2008). The area in which this species is distributed is approximately 286 km².
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Site protection is required to reduce the rate of habitat degradation occurring within this species' range and provide a safeguard for this species. Population monitoring of this species is recommended.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because it is known only from the type locality in the foothill of an active volcano. It may be truly endemic to this area, in which case it might be at significant risk from volcanic activity, or it might be more widespread in an area where no major threats are known to exist.
habitat: This species inhabits in the high Andean areas, in volcanic scree with grasslands and bushes in between. It is terrestrial, viviparous and feeds mainly on insects.
threats: The main potential threat to this species is the Copahue volcano, which is active but hasn't undergone recent eruptions (C. Abdala pers. comm. 2016). Given the uncertainty over the distribution of this species, it is unknown whether this is a major or a localized threat.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species. It is locally common.
range: Liolaemus neuquensis is endemic to Argentina occurring in the region of Volcán Copahue, province of Neuquén (Scolaro et al. 2007, Avila et al. 2013). It occurs at elevations between 2,000 m and 2,200 m. The distributional range of this species is almost unknown and although it's been only documented in volcanic scree habitats, according to L. Avila (pers. comm. 2016) the range is likely to be larger and not limited to active volcanic areas.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is classified as Non Threatened in Argentina (Abdala et al. 2012). It is present in at least one protected area (Area Natural Protegida Copahue).

rationale: This species is listed as Vulnerable because of its very small distribution (with an extent of occurrence of 78 km<sup>2</sup>) and occurrence in a single location, which is at the base of an active volcano. Although there are no anthropogenic threats (as the human population has been evacuated and prohibited from returning), a major volcanic eruption would likely cause a rapid population decline and destruction of its habitat, which might cause the extinction of the species and would at least be likely to qualify it for an immediate listing of Critically Endangered.
habitat: From its distribution it can be inferred that this species is found in Pampas steppe. It is a saxicolous species, viviparous and feeds mainly on plant material (Abdala et al. 2012).
threats: This species is not subject to any known anthropogenic threats; due to both past and ongoing volcanic activity human occupation of this area is prohibited. It occurs near a volcano that has erupted in the past. The effect of past eruptions on the population is unknown; this volcano is however presently active and there is at least a plausible risk of a future eruption resulting in habitat loss or population declines.
population: This species is uncommon within its range. It occurs in a fairly remote area with difficult access such that there has been few expeditions to the region. However, the species is found every time it is searched for, most recently in 2011 (L. Avila, unpublished data). Nearby volcanic activity is having an unknown affect on the population.
range: Liolaemus thermarum is endemic to Argentina, where it is restricted to an small valley near Volcan Peteroa, Malargüe, Mendoza province (Abdala et al. 2012, L. Avila pers. comm. 2016). This species inhabits the foothills of an active volcano (C. Abdala pers. comm. 2016). It is presently known only from the description, however, as searches elsewhere have failed to locate additional subpopulations it is thought to be genuinely confined to this area (C. Abdala pers. comm. 2016). It occurs at elevations of 2400 - 2600 m.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It does not occur in any protected area.

Classified as Vulnerable in Argentina because of its small distribution and low population density (Abdala et al. 2012).

rationale: This species is listed as Vulnerable because it is known only from one location in the foothills of an active volcano. A major eruption would affect the entire range of the species and rapidly cause a category change to Critically Endangered or Extinct.
habitat: This species is from Altoandina phytogeographic province, occurs in the Andean ecotonal zones between open antarctandic forests formed by Araucaria (Araucaria araucana) and areas recovered by Chusquea sp. It is a common species in areas characterized by clay sediments on the slopes of the Copahue volcano. Remarkably, Liolaemus tregenzai has often been found near snow deposits, and close to thawing snow, which frequently form streams. The diet of L. tregenzai is almost completely herbivorous. Nothing is known about other aspects of its natural history, and its reproductive mode is unknown (Pincheira-Donoso and Scolaro 2007).
threats: The main threat to this species is the Copahue Volcano; while this is active it hasn't undergone eruptions recently (C. Abdala pers. comm. 2016). Nevertheless, this species appears to be more strictly restricted to a small area of the volcano's slope than a number of other Liolaemus species found in close association with volcanoes (L. Avila pers. comm. 2016). As such, this species is likely to be at elevated risk from future volcanic activity.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species. It is rare.
range: Liolaemus tregenzai is known only from Copahue Volcano slopes, near Termas del Copahue, Departamento de Ñorquín, Neuquén Province, in north-western Patagonia of Argentina, located at 2,150 m asl (Pincheira-Donoso and Scolaro 2007). The volcano hasn't undergone recent eruptions (C. Abdala pers. comm. 2016). The area of occupancy is estimated in approximately 10 km2, and this species may be strictly endemic to this area (L. Avila pers. comm. 2016).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Classified as Vulnerable in Argentina because of tourism development, and a future geothermic project planned for the near future coupled with its apparent low density (Abdala et al. 2012). It is present in a protected area (Area Natural Protegida Copahue).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) given that, after it experienced a precipitous population decline in the 1980s, no live individuals have been reported since 1989, despite intensive and ongoing searches in suitable habitat in historical localities, suggesting that if this species is still extant the pool of remaining mature individuals is likely fewer than 50.
habitat: It occurs within páramo or subpáramo habitats, which comprise tropical montane vegetation above the treeline (Coloma et al. 2010). Individuals appear to have been found in grassy irrigation ditches, under loose black rocks and within bunched grasses and woody bamboo (P.A. Burrowes field notes, 25 February 1984, in Coloma et al. 2010). Adults have also been found under rocks within a rocky stream bed. Reproduction is year-round by larval development, where eggs are laid in clear, non-contaminated waters in mountain creeks. No tadpoles were ever observed near human habitations in urban areas (Gómez Castillo 1982, 1993), suggesting that this species may not have tolerance to habitat alteration.
threats: Given the past dramatic population decline, and given similar patterns with congeners elsewhere in the tropical Andes, climate change and pathogens (such as Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis) are suspected as possible threat factors (Coloma et al. 2010), although both of these need to be verified for this species and area. It may also be possible that land use change could be a threat, as recent satellite images suggest that the area is now substantially modified for agricultural activities. Emission of volcanic ash from Volcán Galeras in 1993 may also have contributed to the decline (Mueses-Cisneros and Perdomo-Castillo 2011).
population: Formerly abundant in the 1980s, no live individual has been found since 1989 (Coloma et al. 2010). Unconfirmed visual records were made in 1994 and 2002 by local people (Mueses-Cisneros 2005 in Coloma et al. 2010), but no new records have been reported, in spite of intensive search efforts in historical localities since the mid-1990s (Cepeda-Quilindo and Rueda-Almonacid 2005) up until 2004 (Mueses-Cisneros 2005 in Coloma et al. 2010).
range: This species is known only from the region and surrounding areas between Volcán Galeras eastward to Laguna de la Cocha (also known as Laguna del Encano) in the Pasto Massif of the Andean Cordillera, in Department of Nariño and the upper portion of the Valle de Sibundoy, Department of Putumayo, southern Colombia (Coloma et al. 2010). Its elevational range varies between 2,800–3,280 m asl (Coloma et al. 2010). The last known individual was collected in Municipio Consacá in the surroundings of Volcán Galeras (Coloma et al. 2010).
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation ActionsIt is not known to occur in any protected areas.

Research Needed
Surveys are required to determine whether it is still present at past known localities as well as in suitable habitat elsewhere. Further research is needed to determine whether chytrid fungus is present in its historical range and the possible impacts of climate change.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited (EOO of [XXX] km2), there are no current threats, the species adapts to disturbed habitats, and it occurs in a protected area."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited, there are no current threats, it has a stable population, and it occurs in a well-protected area.
habitat: This species inhabits arboreal microhabitats in mossy and montane rainforests, and deposits its eggs on leaves in shrub layer vegetation. It breeds by direct development.
threats: Of the two sites at which the species occurs, Mt. Isarog is presently a generally well-protected locality where the species is not highly threatened by habitat loss. Geothermal energy is generated on the slopes Mt. Malinao, but its impact is limited and one of the plants was recently decommissioned due to decrease in steam supply (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017). Both sites where the species is known to occur are dormant volcanoes, however it is not thought to be at risk of extinction from future volcanic activity.
population: It is common in mid- to upper-montane forests on Mount Isarog. The population appears to be stable.
range: This species was previously known only from Mount Isarog on southeastern Luzon Island, Philippines. It has now been confirmed as also occurring on Mount Malinao (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017). Its elevational range is 650–1,800 m asl and the extent of occurrence (EOO) of this expanded range is 640 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There are no records of this species being utilized."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in Mount Isarog National Park.

Conservation Needed
The most important conservation measure needed at present is the continued management of Mount Isarog National Park.

Research Needed
There is also a need for continued monitoring of the population status of this species.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited - its extent of occurrence (EOO) is XXX km2, there are no current threats, the species adapts to disturbed habitats, and it occurs in a protected area."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited—its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 13,201 km<sup>2</sup>—the population is considered to be stable, the species adapts to a wide range of habitats types and qualities, and is probably not significantly threatened.
habitat: This species inhabits lower montane and lowland forests, where it is found in forest, along forest edges, and in secondary growth vegetation. It has also been found in the axils of Abaca (Muca) plants (A. Diesmos pers. comm. March 2018). This is a highly adaptable species that also occurs in modified habitats beside forests. It lives and presumably breeds in water-filled tree-holes and hollows.
threats: <span id="docs-internal-guid-24b50aa7-88cd-738c-679e-b174c8d0543f">Habitat loss due to small-scale shifting agriculture, expanding human settlements, wood collection for firewood and charcoal production, and illegal logging by commercial entities is taking place (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017). However, this species is adaptable and is probably not significantly threatened.
population: <span lang="EN-GB">It is a common species in appropriate habitat (A. Diesmos pers. comm. March 2018). Its population is presumed to be stable.
range: This species is found on Catanduanes Island and on several mountains of the Bicol Peninsula of Luzon Island, in the Philippines, from 0–800 m asl. <span lang="EN-GB">It is expected to be found more widely in other, similar forested mountain habitats within the Bicol Peninsula (A. Diesmos pers. comm. March 2018). Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 13,201 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in Mount Isarog and Bulusan Volcano Natural Parks on Luzon Island. Since the 2004 assessment, in collaboration with various regional academic institutions, NGO-led awareness campaigns have been taking place to educate the public regarding the need to protect remaining forests on Luzon Island, resulting in positive responses by local communities and improved protection for priority species (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).

Conservation Needed
A protected area needs to be established on the island of Catanduanes to protect this island's biodiversity.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and trends.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in XX threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 9,980 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in three threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat on Luzon Island in the Philippines.
habitat: This species inhabits arboreal microhabitats in mossy and montane rainforests. It deposits its eggs in shrub layer vegetation, in tree ferns, aerial ferns and pandanus. It breeds by direct development.
threats: There are low levels of deforestation at high elevations where this species occurs (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017). Mount Bataan is a dormant volcano, though volcanic eruptions may pose a potential future threat to the subpopulation occurring there. The main threat to the subpopulation in the Zambales Mountain Range is chromite mining.
population: It is very common above 800 m asl on Mount Banahaw, and the population appears to be stable.
range: This species was previously only known only from Mount Banahaw, on Luzon Island, in the Philippines. Its range has now been extended to Mount Bataan and Zambales Mountain Range (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 9,980 km<sup>2 </sup>and all individuals are considered to occur in three threat-defined locations.
useTrade: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There are no records of this species being utilized."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in Mount Banahaw-San Cristobal National Park and Bataan National Park.

Conservation Needed
The most important conservation measure needed is the continued management of the national parks.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Classified as Vulnerable (D2) because it is known only from the type locality that it is on the slopes of Volcán Villarica, one of the most actives volcanoes in Chile and the species could very rapidly decline to Critically Endangered or extinction if an eruption affects the locality.
habitat: This grassland species is oviparous (Pincheira-Donoso et al. 2008) and it is omnivorous (H. Núñez and P. Victoriano pers comm. 2015).
threats: The Villarrica Volcano is one of the most active volcanoes in Chile. Additionally, it is developed both for tourism both for skiing and for volcano viewing. During the summer, when lizards are active, the ski slopes are maintained through levelling, clearance of debris and other activities which are likely to cause some level of disturbance to the species (H. Núñez pers. comm. 2016), although probably do not represent threats to its survival.
population: The species is common in its type locality.
range: This species is endemic to Chile, known only from Volcán Villarrica and surrounding areas, La Araucanía Region (Pincheira-Donoso and Núñez 2005). It has an elevational range between 1,300 and 1,600 m asl (Pincheira-Donoso et al. 2008).
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded to any significant degree.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Better information is needed on current distribution, abundance, and population trend.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened on the basis that this species lost much of its range following volcanic activity in the late 1990s; on the assumption that this species was equally abundant in forest across the island, it is likely to have lost approximately 30% of its global population at this time. Forest loss resulting from volcanic activity peaked in 1998, undoubtedly more than three generations prior to this assessment, and so population declines are at a rate slightly lower than that required to warrant listing the species as Vulnerable, and most surviving habitat where this species occurs is outside the area at risk from future activity. There are localized ongoing pressures from habitat loss and invasive species in the species' remaining range, an area of less than 500 km<sup>2</sup>, but it is not thought to be at risk of extinction in the near future and is likely to occur at more than 10 locations defined by ongoing threats.
habitat: This largely arboreal species is found in forest habitats, including both dry and evergreen forest as well as open situations as long as trees remain. Animals can be found in gardens and villages. It is an egg laying species (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: Volcanic activity began in 1995 and is still ongoing at lower intensity. This appears to have drastically affected the range of this species; if the results obtained by Munoz and Hewlitt (2011) are representative of the whole area impacted by the volcano, the species may have effectively lost a third to half its range within the last 20 years. Measurements of the extent of suitable habitat suggest that this has contracted from perhaps 112 to 47 km<sup>2</sup> as a result of volcanic activity. Little of the species' remaining range is within an area at direct risk from volcanic activity, so this is a past pressure. In recent years, human populations have returned to Montserrat and are settling in the previously largely undisturbed north. This species is only tolerant of a degree of human disturbance, and may be impacted by urban and infrastructure development and greater numbers of cats and rats; the latter are especially abundant in areas with many naturalized exotic fruit trees, including mangoes. At present it seems likely that many of these pressures are localized, and rats seem unlikely to drive the species to extinction.
population: This species was very abundant and widespread before the latest period of volcanic activity, which began in 1995. It is still likely to be common in the island's north, although recent returning human populations now settling in this formerly undisturbed area may have an impact. Following volcanic activity, only a single adult male was recorded in the volcanic exclusion zone in surveys undertaken in 2009 and 2010, conducted in areas of apparently suitable habitat (Muñoz and Hewlitt 2011).
range: This species is endemic to Montserrat, where it occurs island-wide. The species can reach elevations to about 760 m asl (Henderson and Powell 2009).
useTrade: There is no known use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species occurs in the Central Hills protected area, where surveys suggest it is still abundant (transect surveys found between 1.25 and 2.33 per 100 m -Young 2008). Exotic anoles may represent a potential threat; a colony of Anolis leachii was recorded at Montserrat airport immediately before the volcanic eruption. While it is not known whether this colony survived, monitoring is recommended to ensure that no exotic anole populations become established.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species is generally common to abundant, adapts well to plantation agriculture where sufficient leaf litter remains, and is not thought to be subject to major threats. The Montserrat subpopulation was undoubtedly severely impacted by volcanic activity that peaked in the late 1990s. With an area of 102 km<sup>2</sup> Montserrat is the smallest major island on which the species occurs and recent surveys have found the species to be abundant in parts of the island not affected by the volcano, so this must be considered a localized pressure.
habitat: This species is found in mesic habitats including humid forests, swamp forest (R. Gomès pers. comm. 2015), coastal vegetation (Terminalia, Hippomane, Coccoloba, Cocos, and Acacia), on the edge of sugarcane fields, banana groves, and fruit tree stands. It is also found in xeric woodlands.  It is usually associated with leaf litter and other surface debris; multivariate analyses reveal a significant association with deep leaf litter, high canopy cover and high humidity in Montserrat (Daltry 1999). The diet consists of small invertebrates. It is an egg-laying species (Henderson and Powell 2009). It ranges from sea level to 650 m asl. in humid forest in Guadeloupe (Breuil 2002).
threats: There are not thought to be widespread threats to this species on Guadeloupe (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2015). Volcanic activity is likely to have caused a severe range contraction on Montserrat over the past 20 years, however, this represents a limited part of the species' range. Young (2008) describes the species as abundant in the Centre Hills, at the edge of the volcanic exclusion zone; in contrast to Daltry (1999) this author found that the species was more abundant in dry than moist forest. It is not thought to be subject to major threats in Dominica (R. Powell pers. comm. 2015).
population: The species was extremely abundant on Montserrat before the volcanic eruption in 1995, particularly in moister forest habitats with good leaf litter cover although it was widespread throughout the island. It is likely to have lost at least a third of its range on the island following the eruption, including the wetter area which may have represented the best habitat (J. Daltry pers. comm. 2015), however, Montserrat represents a relatively small part of this species' range. It is very common on Guadeloupe (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2015); it occurs at a recorded density of one individual per m2 on Grande-Terre (Breuil 2002). On Dominica it is not present everywhere, but is locally abundant. Densities from 330 to 7,650 per ha have been reported at three different sites on this island, with the highest densities in Coccoloba (Sea Grape) litter (Turk et al. 2010).
range: This West Indies species occurs on several islands of the central Lesser Antilles (Henderson and Powell 2009). It has been confirmed from Montserrat, Guadeloupe and its outlying islands (where it is widespread), Marie-Galante, and along the west coast of Dominica.
useTrade: This species occasionally turns up in the pet trade.
conservationActions: This species occurs in protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated to be 224 km<sup>2</sup>, its population is considered to be severely fragmented, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in southern Chile. Although it is likely that the species may be found in additional sites and that the estimated AOO would increase as a result of this, the current assessment is precautionary given known threats and past declines experienced by the species and assuming that at least some of the potential new sites may have also been affected.
habitat: This species generally occurs in the leaf-litter of temperate Nothofagus forests; it is also present in forest bogs. Surveys suggest that it is not very tolerant of habitat disturbance, having been found consistently within well-maintained native forest, and at the most within native forest where wood gathering for firewood takes place (Soto-Azat et al. 2013a). Females deposit eggs in moist and secluded areas, such as mosses and leaf-litter. When the larvae inside the eggs begin to move, adult males ingest the eggs and incubate them in vocal sacs. Larvae develop inside the male and emerge after metamorphosis. The generation length is estimated to be an average of 11 years based on reproductive ages of 6-15 years (J.C. Ortiz, C. Castro, C. Tala, R. Avilés and A. Charrier pers. comm. July 2015).
threats:
In the north, the main threats are pine forestry and drought, while in the south it is clear-cutting of forest and replacement of native forest with tree plantations (A. Charrier and C. Castro pers. comm. July 2015). Forest fires may also be a threat (C. Castro pers. comm. July 2015). There is recent evidence of chytridiomycosis associated to mortality at the individual level, but also with declines and potential extinction at the local subpopulation level (Soto-Azat et al. 2013b, A. Valenzuela-Sánchez pers. comm. July 2015). Volcanic eruptions may have an impact on some subpopulations (C. Soto-Azat pers. comm. July 2015) and climate change could possibly also affect a subsection of the range; however this requires further research.

In Argentina, based on the fact that the species is entirely included in national parks, there are few threats of anthropogenic origin. In the past, forest exploitation, fires, and livestock in the forest affected the habitat of this species (C. Úbeda and H. Pastore pers. comm. August 2017). Periodic volcanic eruptions do continue to affect important areas of the geographic range.
population:
Historically this species was relatively abundant until the 1980s (R. Avilés pers. comm. July 2015). However there have been subsequent declines and extirpations. The subpopulation of Monumento Natural Cerro Ñielol has disappeared completely since 1980, and that of Nahuelbuta National Park and Melimoyu (Aysen region) have experienced severe declines around 2000, with just 1-2 individuals recorded in the last five years despite intense and targeted surveys (C. Soto-Azat and A. Charrier pers. comm. July 2015). 

Its population is considered to be severely fragmented as per IUCN definitions. Despite a large historial distribution, at present, the species is currently known from a very small percentage of this area in small and severely fragmented subpopulations. This species has high site fidelity (home ranges of only 1–3 m2) and dispersal limitations, and is also highly specialized, living only in certain areas within the forest forming colonies. It is only known from 56 localities (in Chile), each of them isolated and independent subpopulations (C. Soto-Azat pers. comm. August 2017).

In Chile, there are 103 recognized historical sites documented between 1834 to 2000 (evidence of historical presence was based on museum specimens). All of these sites have been recently visited and only 16 have been confirmed to still have the species (Soto-Azat et al. 2013a). The species is now known to occur at 56 sites in Chile, including the 16 historical sites at which it can still be found (C. Soto-Azat pers. comm. August 2017). Recent population estimates vary between 10-105 individuals per subpopulation, including adults and juveniles; the latter comprise roughly 25% of individuals recorded (Soto-Azat et al. 2013a, A. Valenzuela pers. comm. July 2015).

In Argentina, there are 41 recognized historical sites between 1896 to present, of which only 11 sites have evidence of the species after 2000. In this country, this is a scarce species and appears to have declined at two sites (Puerto Blest, Nahuel Huapi National Park and Villa La Angostura, Neuquén Province) during the past 50 years. Since the 1990s, specific surveys have recorded few individuals within suitable habitats (C. Úbeda pers comm. August 2017).
range:
This species is endemic to the austral forest of Chile and Argentina, although it occurs tangentially in the latter country (Soto-Azat et al. 2013). Historically, it was distributed in Chile from Concepción to Aysen Province (Río Cuervo). Currently, it can be found in at least 45 sites in Chile (Soto-Azat et al. 2013a, Darwin’s frog Conservation Strategy Workshop 2017), from Cuyinco Alto (Cordillera Nahuelbuta) to Río Cuervo, and including Chiloé and Mocha Islands. The islands that make up the Chonos Archipelago (south of Chiloé) were previously mapped as part of this species' distribution; however there are no records of it occurring there to date (C. Soto pers. comm. January 2017) and they have been removed from the map. In Argentina, it is known from Neuquén, Chubut and Río Negro provinces, where there are 11 localities with confirmed presence of the species since 2000, all of them located in two national parks, Lanín National Park and Nahuel Huapi National Park (Úbeda and Pastore 2015). It has an altitudinal range of 0–1,340 m asl (Úbeda and Pastore 2015).

Despite the fact that the population has a widespread range, it has been found to occupy circumscribed areas within suitable habitat (C. Soto-Azat pers. comm. July 2015). Based on known spatial occupancy and individual home range (1.82 m2, Valenzuela et al. 2014), it is assumed that each site is no larger than 4 km2 (in fact, many subpopulations in Chile are known to use less than 300 m2 of forest; Soto-Azat et al. 2013a). Assuming that each of the known sites is comparable with regards to internal occupancy, the total AOO is estimated to be 224 km2. Its EOO is 160,446 km2. In Argentina, there is no evidence of range retraction. Further surveys may extend the southern limit of distribution because there are suitable habitats under the protection of national parks (Úbeda and Pastore 2015). There is uncertainty on whether there are other non-reported subpopulations within its range, particularly in between known sites and towards southern latitudes where remote areas are difficult to access and have not been thoroughly surveyed. If new subpopulations are discovered and the AOO experiences a considerable increase, a change of category to Vulnerable is possible.
useTrade: It used to be encountered in the pet trade until the late 1990s; however, it is no longer found in trade. It is not listed on CITES (C. Soto-Azat pers. comm. July 2015).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
There are several protected areas in the range of the species. In Chile, it is listed as "Endangered" (En Peligro de Extinción) (Reglamento de Clasificación de Especies, Chile, 2011) and there are currently two ex situ initiatives, led by Universidad de Concepción - Zoo Leipzig (since 2009) and Zoológico Nacional de Chile - San Antonio Zoo, Texas since 2010 (C. Castro, A. Charrier pers. comm. July 2015). An in-situ initiative between Universidad Andrés Bello, Ranita de Darwin NGO, HuiloHuilo, Tantauco and Melimoyu private reserves has been implemented to investigate and provide further protection to the species (C. Soto-Azat pers. comm. July 2016). In Argentina, its range is entirely comprised of two national parks - Lanín and Nahuel Huapi - in western sectors, that have a relatively good status of conservation of its habitats.

Conservation Needed
There remains a need for improved maintenance and protection of native forest habitats, particularly in the north. 

Research Needed
Close population monitoring of known subpopulations is required given the declines seen in suitable habitat. The potential of climate change is also required to determine the potential threat. Targeted surveys to unexplored areas with suitable habitat in between known sites as well as the more remote areas are required to determine if the species may also occur there.

rationale: While historic and recent population estimates are quite imprecise, even the best-case scenarios indicate a population collapse of well over half from historical levels less than three generations ago (at a generation time of 60 years), resulting primarily from past exploitation and, more recently, occasional poaching, qualifying the Wolf Volcano Tortoise as Vulnerable, VU A1bde. This species was previously assessed for the Red List in 1996 as Chelonoidis nigra ssp. becki (VU D1+2). This assessment also incorporates knowledge contributions from participants of the international workshop on Galápagos tortoises convened by the Galápagos National Park Directorate in July 2012.
habitat: Chelonoidis becki is a large insular tortoise with an intermediate domed to slightly saddlebacked carapace with a vegetarian diet, adapted for grazing on low-growing vegetation as well as browsing on higher-growing vegetation in drier shrubland ecosystems. While detailed life history information is not available for wild animals, by analogy with captive animals and other Galápagos tortoises it is likely to mature at an age of 20 years or later, with an estimated generation time of 60 years.
threats: Galápagos Tortoises were decimated by overexploitation by humans for food, both by sailors taking tortoises on board as food supply, as well as by local settlers. While there is no known documented evidence of this for Chelonoidis becki, it is probable that the population was also exploited. Occasional poaching of tortoises has occurred in the last 25 years. The depleted C. becki population was potentially further impacted by the effects of introduced species, including rats, mice, cats, and goats (eradicated in 2006). In addition, eruptions of Wolf Volcano pose an unpredictable risk to tortoises due to their restricted occurrence on the southern and eastern flanks of the volcano. Genetic data suggest that the two genetically distinct subpopulations of tortoises of C. becki now residing in Piedras Blancas (northern) and Puerto Bravo (western) may be fusing back together due to lava flow changes resulting in tortoise trails between these two areas. As this is believed to be the result of natural processes, no conservation management of these two lineages is required (Garrick et al. 2014).
population: Based on an estimated average density of one tortoise per hectare of suitable habitat, the historical population size may have been about 25,000 adults (J.P. Gibbs unpubl. data). In the early 1970s, the population was estimated at 1,000-2,000 tortoises (MacFarland et al. 1974). Currently, the population comprises at least 2000 marked adults (Garrick et al. 2012, 2014; Edwards et al. 2013), and is thought to include 7,000-8,000 animals (W. Tapia, pers. comm.).
range: Chelonoidis becki occurs on the northern, western, and southwestern slopes of Wolf Volcano, with a small group on an isolated plateau inside the crater, northern Isabela (formerly Albemarle Island) in the Galápagos Islands of Ecuador (Pritchard 1996). The northeastern and eastern slopes are little explored. The potential range of C. becki comprises about 263 sq. km.
useTrade: There is no direct evidence of exploitation of Wolf Volcano tortoises by 19th century whalers  (Pritchard 1996). However, although access to interior populations may have been difficult, tortoises ranged (and still do) to the shoreline and would have been vulnerable to whalers.  Recent reports of finds of slaughtered animals indicate some ongoing exploitation, possibly by illegal fishers (Cayot and Lewis 1994).
conservationActions: Legislation & regulations: Chelonoidis becki is protected under Ecuadorian national law. It has been included in Appendix I of CITES since 1975, prohibiting all forms of commercial international trade. Nearly all of Isabela including 100% of Wolf Volcano, and thus the entire native range of C. becki, are protected as part of the Galápagos National Park. Goat eradication from the three northern volcanoes of Isabela was confirmed in 2006. Conservation actions needed: further genetic analysis, removal of hybrid tortoises with high conservation value (to be used in breeding programs for other islands), and continued population monitoring and control of poaching.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) is [XXX] km2, it occurs in XX threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) is 12,387 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five to seven threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat mainly due to agricultural activities and other anthropogenic threats in northeastern Ecuador and southern Colombia.
habitat: This species occurs in cloud forest, and is associated with stream habitats (Lynch and Duellman 1980). It is presumed to breed by direct development, but the site of egg deposition is not known. The ability of this species to adapt to modified habitats is unknown. There is continuing decline in the extent and quality of the habitat due to agricultural activities and other human-induced threats.
threats: The major threat is habitat loss due to agriculture (including the planting of illegal crops) and logging. The localities at the base of El Reventador volcano in Ecuador are affected by the development of an hydroelectric dam, and also by the eruptions of the volcano (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016). In Colombia, part of the distribution is threatened by mining activities (Colombia Red List Assessment Workshop August 2016). Some other species in the same genus that are associated with streams have undergone dramatic declines and disappearances, possibly due to disease, so the status of this species should be monitored carefully.
population: Generally, this is not a common frog anywhere in its range, although a considerable-sized series was collected in 1990 in Parque Nacional Natural Alto Fragua-Indiwasi, Colombia. <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species occurs on the eastern slopes of the Andes in Putumayo and Caquetá (Colombia) and Napo (Ecuador), at elevations between 1,440-1,950 m asl. In Ecuador it is only known from three nearby localities. Another locality in Canton Loreto, Orellana Province by Lynch and Duellman (1980) may be an error given that it is at 400 m asl (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016), and is therefore considered Presence Uncertain in the distribution map until further clarified. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated as 12,387 km<sup>2</sup> and it occurs in five to seven locations, based on the main threats affecting the species.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Parque Nacional Natural Alto Fragua-Indiwasi in Colombia. 

Research Needed
Research is needed to better determine its population size and trends and the impact of the current threats on its population. Additional studies are needed into this species' natural history and ecology.

rationale: The species is listed as Near Threatened because of the smaller population size at islands, so it is suspected that migration does not occur frequently as to maintain high genetic diversity (Genoways 1988). In addition, severe weather (storms, hurricanes) and even volcanic eruptions, in addition to habitat changes may have fragmented these populations, although it occurs in a few protected areas. Current data almost meet "Vulnerable" under criterion B1a, with an extent of occurrence (EOO) of less than 15,504 km², although there is no evidence of continuing decline in populations.
habitat: Little is known of the ecology of this species, presumably it is the locally dominantly frugivorous as are other members of the genus (Jones and Genoways 1975). A male from Guadeloupe was the only specimen taken in a net set in a deep ravine that was located in "an area of extremely dense forest" (de la Torre and Schwartz 1966), a series from Dominica was taken in nets set across two streams described as "fairly placid and not torrential at the localities of the nets", both streams were in rainforests with no adjacent cultivated areas (de la Torre 1966). These studies reveal that Sturnira species could be relatively uncommon and unlike other frugivorous bats possibly needs native humid forests instead of tropical agriculture to flourish (Genoways 1988).
threats: Like other bat species in tropical islands, Sturnira angeli is subject to natural threats like hurricanes or volcanic eruptions (Genoways 1988; Pedersen et al. 2006, 2013). Change of land cover, and agriculture use are among the typical threats to its populations.
population: Studies at the Lesser Antilles reveal that Sturnira species could be relatively uncommon and unlike other frugivorous bats possibly needs native humid forests instead of tropical agriculture to flourish (Genoways 1988). Some isolated populations on islands are suspected to be at high risk because of events like hurricanes or volcanic eruptions; plus, species of this genus do not migrate well between islands (Genoways 1988).
range: This species is known from the islands of Martinique, Dominica, Guadeloupe and Montserrat, in the Lesser Antilles (de la Torre 1966, de la Torre and Schwartz 1966, Jones and Phillips 1976, Genoways 1988, Velazco and Patterson 2013). It has been recently split from the widespread and polyphyletic Sturnira lilium (sensu lato) based on phylogenetic analyses of DNA sequences.
conservationActions: Some protected areas (nature parks, nature reserves, national parks) exist on Martinique, Dominica, and Guadeloupe islands, but these are lacking at Montserrat.

rationale: This species has not been recorded in Lake Poso since 1983 and could likely be extinct, possibly due to invasive species and their introduced diseases and parasites (Kottelat and Whitten 1996, Harrison and Stiassny 1999, Parenti 2011) and possibly from overfishing (M.T. Gundo pers. comm. 2017). Surveys in 2012 and 2017 did not recover this species (Mokodongan and Yamahira 2015, Kobayasi and Mokodongan pers. obvs. 2017), although Larson et al. (2014) reported that local people had occasionally still found 'buntingi', a common name for this species, in the lake at low abundances in late 2012 and 2013. It is likely that there are fewer than 50 mature individuals left within the lake and therefore, this species is assessed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) based on criterion D. More fieldwork is required to determine if this species is still extant in Lake Poso.
habitat: This is a pelagic species that is endemic to the freshwater Lake Poso. It differs from other members of its family by its overhanging 'duck-bill' shaped upper jaw and protruding eyes. Females are known to carry a cluster of eggs against their belly, protected by the pelvic fin, until they hatch (Kottelat et al. 1993, Parenti and Soeroto 2004, Parenti 2008).
threats: This species was last recorded in 1983 and may be extinct in Lake Poso. The potential disappearance of this species is thought to be attributed to volcanic and tectonic activities that occurred within the region in 1983. Local people reported large numbers of lake species being washed ashore in drifts that may have been caused by gases being released within the lake (Larson 2001, Larson et al. 2014). Due to geographic location, this remains a possible threat that could occur again in the future, potentially impacting the entire global population of lake endemics. Additionally, unknown invasive species and their parasites and diseases are listed as a likely cause of their population decline (Kottelat and Whitten 1996, Harrison and Stiassny 1999, Parenti 2011). Many invasive species, such as the Common Carp (Cyprinus carpio) and Nile Tilapia (Oreochromis niloticus), have been recorded in this lake. A. kruyti is also thought to have been overfished by local people, and if still extant would be threatened by fishing at night using lights (M.T. Gundo pers. comm. 2017). Deforestation surrounding the lake is likely to reduce water quality due to increases in runoff causing sedimentation and potentially introducing chemical herbicides and pesticides (J. Sulfani Udin pers. comm. 2019).
population: This species has not been recorded in Lake Poso since 1983 and could likely be extinct, possibly due to invasive species and their introduced diseases and parasites (Kottelat and Whitten 1996, Harrison and Stiassny 1999, Parenti 2011). Surveys in 2012 and 2017 did not recover this species (Mokodongan and Yamahira 2015, Kobayasi and Mokodongan pers. obs. 2017), although Larson et al. (2014) reported that local people had occasionally still found 'buntini' or 'buntingi', a common name for this species and the related Adrianichthys roseni, in the lake at low abundances in late 2012 and 2013. Due to this, it is likely that there are fewer than 50 mature individuals left within the lake, but more fieldwork is required to determine if this species is still extant in Lake Poso.
range: This species is endemic to Lake Poso in central Sulawesi, Indonesia (Parenti and Soeroto 2004, Parenti 2008). This species was not found in the lake in 2012 (Mokodongan and Yamahira 2015) and surveys in 2017 also failed to recover this species (Kobayasi and Mokodongan pers. obs. 2017). This species is therefore considered to be possibly extinct within the lake.
useTrade: This species was locally fished for food and, if extant in Lake Poso, would likely still be targeted, especially at night using lights (M.T. Gundo pers. comm. 2017).
conservationActions: There is no information on the conservation measures in place for this species. If it is still extant within Lake Poso, research and monitoring of its population is highly recommended alongside education of local people to highlight the importance of this endemic species and invasive species control.

rationale: The holotype of this species was collected in 1978 (Parenti and Soeroto 2004) and no other recordings have been made since, so this species could likely be extinct (Parenti 2011). Surveys in 2012 and 2017 did not recover this species (Mokodongan and Yamahira 2015, Kobayasi and Mokodongan pers. obs. 2017), although Larson et al. (2014) reported that local people had occasionally still found 'buntingi', a common name for this species and the related Adrianichthys kruyti, in the lake at low abundances in late 2012 and 2013. It is likely that there are fewer than 50 mature individuals left within the lake and therefore, this species is assessed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) based on criterion D. More fieldwork is required to determine if this species is still extant in Lake Poso.
habitat: This species has a maximum standard length of 90 mm and is characterised by its slender body, large eyes and elongated upper and lower jaws. No habitat data are available for this species, but it is thought to be pelagic like other large buntingi in Lake Poso (Parenti and Soeroto 2004).
threats: This species has not been recorded in Lake Poso in many decades. The potential disappearance of this species is thought to be attributed to volcanic and tectonic activities that occurred within the region in 1983. Local people reported large numbers of lake species being washed ashore in drifts that may have been caused by gases being released within the lake (Larson 2001, Larson et al. 2014). Due to geographic location, this remains a possible threat that could occur again in the future, potentially impacting the entire global population of lake endemics. The decline of this species has also been linked to invasive species and their parasites and diseases (Parenti and Soeroto 2004). Many invasive species such as the Common Carp (Cyprinus carpio) and Nile Tilapia (Oreochromis niloticus) have been recorded in this lake. It is also thought to have been overfished by local people, and if still extant would be threatened by fishing at night using lights (M.T. Gundo pers. comm. 2017). Deforestation surrounding the lake is likely to reduce water quality due to increases in runoff causing sedimentation and potentially introducing chemical herbicides and pesticides (J. Sulfani Udin pers. comm. 2019).
population: The holotype of this species was collected in 1978 (Parenti and Soeroto 2004) and no other recordings have been made since, so this species could likely be extinct (Parenti 2011). Surveys in 2012 and 2017 did not recover this species (Mokodongan and Yamahira 2015, Kobayasi and Mokodongan pers. obs. 2017), although Larson et al. (2014) reported that local people had occasionally still found 'buntingi' or 'butini', a common name for this species and the related Adrianichthys kruyti, in the lake at low abundances in late 2012 and 2013. Due to this it is likely that there are fewer than 50 mature individuals left within the lake, but more fieldwork is required to determine if this species is still extant in Lake Poso.
range: This species is endemic to Lake Poso in central Sulawesi, Indonesia (Parenti and Soeroto 2004, Parenti 2008). This species was not found in the lake in 2012 (Mokodongan and Yamahira 2015) and surveys in 2017 also failed to recover this species (Kobayasi and Mokodongan pers. obs. 2017). This species is therefore considered possibly extinct within the lake.
useTrade: This species was locally fished for food and if extant in Lake Poso would likely still be targeted, especially at night using lights (M.T. Gundo pers. comm. 2017).
conservationActions: There is no information on the conservation measures in place for this species. If it is still extant within Lake Poso, research and monitoring of its population is highly recommended alongside education of local people to highlight the importance of this endemic species. Invasive species control may benefit this and other species within the lake.

rationale: Xenopoecilus poptae is a pelagic fish endemic to Lake Poso on the island of Sulawesi, Indonesia. The species is harvested locally as a food resource and is threatened by water quality declines within the lake associated with agricultural runoff. Population trends are unknown due to problems associated with timing of collection. Additional research into the population trend and habitat quality of the species is needed. Due to the species' limited distribution (with an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 500 km2) and the declining water quality within its habitat, it is listed as Endangered under criterion B.
habitat: Xenopoecilus poptae is one of the largest ricefish, with a maximum standard length of 192 mm. It has a slender body with an abdominal concavity that females use to carry eggs until hatching (Parenti 2008). Its exact habitat is unknown, but it is pelagic and is only caught at night using lamps.
threats: The primary threats to freshwater fish within Lake Poso are invasive alien species, eutrophication caused by pollution from multiple sources, and intensive fishing (Parenti and Soeroto 2004). The major threat to this species is likely intensive fishing at night using lamps, as this species is a sought after food fish for communities living around the lake. It is caught using modified nets in both row and motorboats (Gundo 2009, Gundo et al. 2016, D.F. Mokodongan pers. obs. 2012; 2017). Invasive species such as the Common Carp (Cyprinus carpio) and Nile Tilapia (Oreochromis niloticus) have been introduced into the lake for fishing activities, and may impact this species through predation, competition, and the transfer of disease and parasites (Parenti and Soeroto 2004). Lake Poso is also a clear water lake so it is sensitive to pollution from domestic waste and agricultural fertiliser run off (Parenti and Soeroto 2004). In 1983, volcanic and tectonic activities that occurred within the region are considered to have impacted several Lake Poso fish species. Local people reported large numbers of lake species being washed ashore in drifts, that may have been caused by gases being released within the lake (Larson 2001, Larson et al. 2014). Whilst this historic event is thought to have predominantly affected species that inhabit deeper waters in the middle of the lake, all species within the lake were likely impacted. If a similar event occurred in the future, it would pose an additional threat to this species, in combination with all other threats currently identified.
population: There are records of this species from 1999, 2003 (Parenti 2008) and 2012 (Mokodongan and Yamahira 2015), while local people reported in late 2012 and late 2013 that 'bunting', a common name for fish species within Lake Poso, were still occasionally seen within the lake but at low abundances (Larson et al. 2014). Surveys conducted in 2017 failed to produce records of the fish. Local informants suggested that this may have more to do with timing of sampling than absence of the species (D.F. Mokodongan pers. comm. 2018). More surveys are necessary to determine population trajectory.
range: This species is endemic to Lake Poso in central Sulawesi, Indonesia (Parenti 2008).
useTrade: Buntingi fish, which includes Xenopoecilus poptae and related species within Lake Poso, are harvested by local people using modified nets in both row and motorboats (Gundo et al. 2016).
